WEBPREFACE.NAME: Preface of JavaScript Adaptation
WEBPREFACE.TEXT:
These pages contain selected sections of
Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs by Harold Abelson and Gerald Sussman with Julie Sussman, adapted to the programming language JavaScript for online learning.
The programs of the book are given in the original Scheme language. The Scheme programs can be executed (evaluated) by clicking on them. Clicking on the result or on "Play" opens a new window that lets you play with the programs. There is also a version of the book that uses Javascript instead of Scheme, and a version that allows you to compare both.
The programs are also given in JavaScript, translated from Scheme by Martin Henz, and the text is modified to be consistent with JavaScript terminology while retaining as much as possible of the elegance and eloquence of the original SICP. The JavaScript programs, like the Scheme versions, can be executed (evaluated) by clicking on them. Each time, the JavaScript version deviates from the original, this is highlighted visually (using horizontal splits and/or in a different color.
The interpreter is restricted to use only the sublanguage of JavaScript that is used in the respective chapter. We refer to the language used for Chapter 1 as Source 1, the language used for Chapter 2 as Source 2, etc. Descriptions of the respective Source languages are available in an
online folder.
If you are interested, the "Making-of" page contains information on how these pages were generated, and what tools are used under the hood.
